children: A 54-year-old woman is evaluated for unresponsiveness following a thunderclap headache.
Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
The most likely diagnosis is subarachnoid hemorrhage. This patient's CT angiogram

an extensive subarachnoid hemorrhage (blood appearing as white hyperintense areas) with intraventricular extension. CT is very sensitive for detection of subarachnoid hemorrhage, especially when performed soon after symptom onset. Examination findings suggestive of subarachnoid hemorrhage include altered mental status, nuchal rigidity, pupillary dilation from compression of the oculomotor nerve (cranial nerve III) by a posterior communicating artery aneurysm, or subhyaloid hemorrhages on funduscopy. The most common cause of atraumatic subarachnoid hemorrhage is saccular (berry) aneurysm rupture, with intracranial arterial dissection and mycotic aneurysm rupture occurring less commonly.
